content.description:
Reasonably fun climbing up a ramp and around a corner at a notch. 

  Some of the blocks in the back of the corner are loose, but it's fairly easy not to pull them out.
content.protection: You'll need a 4-5" piece for the ramp.  Otherwise, good gear.
content.location: 3 feet to the right of the massive Motorcycle Diarrhias roof.  Climb corner to top.

content.description: The vertical crack-line to the left of Susie Q that shares the same top-out.  Start by the big roof and follow the crack on the right side to the top.  Fun little climb with a mantle.  Several options.
content.protection: Good protection but the top takes a little creativity.
content.location: To the left of Susie Q by the big roof.  Follow the crack on the right side of the big roof to the top.  Shares the same finish as Susie Q.

content.description: Climb up under roof, escape left to top.  Be VERY careful TRing this route (massive pendulum) and be absolutely certain to protect the anchor/rope from the edge; the pendulum will slice the rope.
content.location: 15 feet right of Havana Club, under large roof.  Start at seam in back wall, climb up under roof, escape left to top.

content.description: A decent line in an overlooked section of the cliff.  Combines pleasant steep face climbing down low with a puzzling crux up high that just might remind you of MF.
content.protection: There's adequate gear, but a fall from the crux would be a bad, swinging fall onto the ledge below.  Best to TR from solid trees on top.
content.location: See photo for location, just right of Susie Q.  Climb the steep face along a vertical seam to a ledge.  Stem up the corner to the first overhang; move R onto the front face (crux) then up to the top.

content.description: I can't bring myself to give this one a bomb, but unless you REALLY like squeeze chimneys, this thing is miserable.  I don't mind squeeze chimneys, but this particular one is rather dirty and loose.
content.protection: I TRed it; didn't check for gear.  Gear-only anchor.
content.location: Between Havana Club and Motorcycle Diarrheas, there's a chimney perhaps 15 feet off the ground; climb up into and through the chimney.  Easy walk-off.

content.description: An interesting 5.5 with a very comfortable alcove in which to rest.  Two cruxes - about 10 feet off the ground, and heading up to the anchor in the offwidth.
content.protection: PG pro, with ledge-fall at nearly every point - especially on the exit moves at the top.  Gear/natural-only anchor.
content.location: Start at obvious pile of rocks below dihedral that leads to alcove and large, V-shaped chockstone.  Go up dihedral, pass alcove over chockstone, go up offwidth above to anchor.  Easy walk-off via access trail.

content.description: A thoughtful 5.7 with a tricky move half-way through (crux).
content.location: The thin vertical crack 10 feet left of Havana Club.  Climb vertical crack to top.  Can run Havana Club and Cuba Libre off one anchor with a properly placed directional.

content.description: A slanting finger crack leads to a ledge under the small overhang.  The holds (and gear) are good there, but it's hard to pull the move gracefully.
content.protection: A #3 Camalot protects the crux nicely.  Topropers would do well to consider the route name - keep your rope out of the notch in the overhang!
content.location: Start atop the boulder pile that is immediately right of the Susie Q crack.

content.description: A too-often-overlooked arete that has much the same feel as PK's more traveled aretes (e.g. Exuberance) at a more moderate grade. If the starting corner is wet* you can start the route on the right-side ledge 15 feet up. * Even when the mossy wall is wet, the edge you layback on is likely to be dry, and there's great friction on this.
content.protection: Groundfall from the crux so this is for Toprope. There's a birch tree and slingable boulder on the flat top, just a couple steps off the trail that leads across the cliff top. The pitch pine on the ledge is too far left to be useful, but there's a big one 30 feet straight away along the trail.
content.location: Left end of Little Havana wall. Most easily approached from the trail that leads to the Big Slab/Headbangers area. Start in the mossy, right-facing corner; hand traverse right several feet to the arete; climb the left side of that to the top.

content.description: Small area, but a good alternative when the larger areas are taken.  Very shady, good photo-ops, relatively straightforward gear anchors.  Routes in the 5.5-5.10 range.  Watch out for wasps.
